name: Pentagram
description: The Pentagram is one of the most powerful and widely recognized symbols in Western esoteric tradition. This five-pointed star, drawn with a single continuous line, represents the microcosm of humanity and the macrocosm of the universe. Its proportions embody the golden ratio, making it a supreme symbol of sacred geometry and divine harmony. Throughout history, it has served as a protective talisman, a symbol of the five elements, and a key to understanding the relationship between humanity and the cosmos.
meaning: The five-pointed star representing the five elements (Earth, Water, Fire, Air, Spirit), the microcosm of humanity, sacred geometry through the golden ratio, and the balance of elemental forces in Western esoteric tradition.
visualDescription: A five-pointed star formed by drawing five straight lines that create a continuous, interlocking pattern. The figure can be inscribed within a circle (pentacle) and features the golden ratio in the proportions between its lines. When drawn with one point upward, it represents spirit presiding over matter; inverted, it symbolizes matter dominating spirit.
meanings: The five classical elements: Earth, Water, Fire, Air, and Spirit (Quintessence)
The microcosm - humanity as a reflection of the divine cosmos
Sacred geometry and the golden ratio (phi = 1.618...)
Protection and banishment of negative forces
The five senses and five extremities of the human body
Unity of the four material elements under spiritual governance
The Pythagorean symbol of health and recognition
Balance and harmony between opposing forces

upright.name: Upright Pentagram
upright.description: Single point facing upward, representing Spirit governing the four material elements
symbolism: The macrocosm reflected in the microcosm

inverted.name: Inverted Pentagram
inverted.description: Two points facing upward, representing matter dominating spirit
symbolism: Second degree initiation in some traditions
inverted.historicalContext: The inverted pentagram was not originally considered evil. In ceremonial magic, it represents the second degree of initiation where the aspirant must confront material existence. Its association with Satanism dates primarily to the 19th century through the writings of Eliphas Levi.

goldenRatio.description: The pentagram is the supreme expression of the golden ratio (phi, approximately 1.618034). Every line segment in a pentagram relates to others by the golden ratio.
mathematicalProperties: The ratio of the diagonal to the side equals phi
Each intersection creates segments in golden proportion
The pentagram contains infinite nested pentagrams, each related by phi
goldenRatio.significance: The golden ratio appears throughout nature in growth patterns, spiral shells, flower petals, and the proportions of the human body. The pentagram thus represents the mathematical signature of organic life and divine creation.

methods: Compass and straightedge using golden ratio relationships
Five equal divisions of a circle (72 degrees apart)
Connecting every second point of a regular pentagon
construction.symbolism: The ability to construct a perfect pentagram with compass and straightedge represents the union of geometric precision with organic harmony.

sacredGeometry.pentagonRelationship: The pentagram and pentagon are intimately related - a pentagram inscribed in a pentagon creates a smaller pentagon at its center, which can contain another pentagram, ad infinitum. This infinite regression symbolizes the fractal nature of reality.

prehistoric.details: The earliest known pentagrams appear in Sumerian pottery and astronomical texts, where they represented the planet Venus and its five-pointed path across the sky over an eight-year cycle.

pythagorean.details: The Pythagoreans adopted the pentagram as their secret symbol of recognition, calling it 'Hugieia' (Health). They discovered its mathematical properties and considered it a symbol of perfection and the golden ratio.
significance: Demonstrated the golden ratio's presence in geometry

usage: Symbol of the five wounds of Christ
Representation of the Star of Bethlehem
Carved on church doorways and grave markers
christian.examples: Sir Gawain and the Green Knight describes the pentangle on Gawain's shield as representing the five virtues of knighthood, the five joys of Mary, and the five wounds of Christ.

developments: Association with the human microcosm (Vitruvian proportions)

goldenDawn.organization: Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn

lesserBanishingRitual.name: Lesser Banishing Ritual of the Pentagram (LBRP)
lesserBanishingRitual.description: The foundational ritual of Golden Dawn magic, used to clear a space of unwanted influences and establish a protected magical working area.
components: Drawing pentagrams at the four quarters

greaterRitual.name: Greater Ritual of the Pentagram
greaterRitual.description: Advanced form using specific pentagrams for invoking or banishing each element, utilizing the elemental attributions of the pentagram's points.
variations: Invoking pentagrams (draw toward the element's point)
Banishing pentagrams (draw away from the element's point)
Spirit Active and Spirit Passive pentagrams

elemental.invokingMethod: To invoke an element, draw the pentagram starting from the point opposite that element and moving toward it.
elemental.banishingMethod: To banish an element, draw the pentagram starting from that element's point and moving away from it.
elemental.spiritActive: Used with Fire and Air (masculine elements)
elemental.spiritPassive: Used with Water and Earth (feminine elements)

starRuby.name: The Star Ruby
starRuby.description: Crowley's Thelemic reformulation of the LBRP, using Greek and Egyptian god-names instead of Hebrew divine names.
elements: NOX signs replacing the Qabalistic Cross
Greek deity invocations (Therion, Nuit, Babalon, Hadit)

liber36.name: The Star Sapphire
liber36.description: A sexual magical ritual incorporating pentagram symbolism with the union of opposites.

thelema.philosophy: In Thelema, the pentagram represents the microcosm and the individual will. The formula of the pentagram is the formula of the initiated human being in harmony with the universe.

solomonic.keyOfSolomon: The Key of Solomon features the pentagram prominently in its protective seals and magical operations.

wiccan.significance: The pentagram is the primary symbol of Wicca, representing the five elements and the interconnection of all life.

pentacle.description: A pentagram enclosed within a circle, often worn as jewelry or placed on the altar
usage: Primary altar tool representing Earth element

initiation.firstDegree: Upright pentagram - the beginning of the path
initiation.secondDegree: Inverted pentagram - facing the material world
initiation.thirdDegree: Return to upright - mastery and teaching

wiccan.sabbats: The pentagram appears in rituals throughout the Wheel of the Year, often drawn in the air or used as a consecrating symbol.

usage: Representation of the Goddess and God
Connection to nature and natural cycles

symbolism: The five wounds of Christ (hands, feet, side)

gnostic.tradition: Christian Gnostic and early Christian mysticism

christianUsage.decline: The pentagram's association with Christianity declined during the witch trial era (15th-18th centuries) as it became associated with folk magic and eventually with occultism through the writings of Eliphas Levi.

christianSignificance.overview: The pentagram has a complex but significant history in Christian tradition. For over a millennium, it was a respected Christian symbol representing the five wounds of Christ, divine protection, and spiritual perfection. Its association with the occult is a relatively recent development (19th century onwards). Understanding the pentagram's Christian history helps recover its legitimate place in medieval Christian iconography.

scriptural.text: But one of the soldiers pierced his side with a spear, and at once there came out blood and water
scriptural.significance: The wound in Christ's side - the fifth wound

scriptural.text: Unless I see in his hands the mark of the nails, and place my finger into the mark of the nails, and place my hand into his side, I will never believe
scriptural.significance: Thomas invited to touch the wounds in Christ's hands and side - establishing the four wounds

scriptural.text: They will look on me, the one they have pierced
But he was pierced for our transgressions
scriptural.significance: The salvific meaning of Christ's wounds

fiveWounds.devotionalTradition: Medieval devotion to the Five Sacred Wounds of Christ (two hands, two feet, side) was deeply embedded in Catholic piety. The pentagram served as a visual reminder of these wounds through which salvation came.

starOfBethlehem.description: The star that guided the Magi to the Christ child. While Scripture does not specify its shape, medieval artists sometimes depicted it as a five-pointed star, linking the pentagram to Christ's birth.
starOfBethlehem.liturgical: The Epiphany (January 6) celebrates the Magi's visit, and five-pointed stars often appear in church decorations for this feast.

fivefoldPatterns.pattern: The five books of the Torah (Pentateuch)
fivefoldPatterns.significance: Foundation of God's revelation completed in Christ
Christ as the greater David defeating the enemy

fivefoldPatterns.pattern: The five loaves feeding the multitude (John 6:9)
fivefoldPatterns.significance: Christ as the Bread of Life

earlyChurch.description: The pentagram appeared in early Christian contexts, though less prominently than the cross or Chi-Rho. Some early Christians associated it with the five letters of the Greek word for health (ΥΓΕΙΑ), connected to Christ as healer.
earlyChurch.gnosticUse: Gnostic Christians used the pentagram extensively, associating it with the five elements and spiritual knowledge. While orthodox Christianity rejected Gnostic theology, the symbol's presence demonstrates early Christian engagement.

medievalPeriod.prominence: The pentagram reached its height of Christian use during the Middle Ages. It appeared on churches, cathedrals, manuscripts, and religious objects throughout Christendom.
meanings: The Five Wounds of Christ - primary and most common interpretation
The Five Joys of Mary (Annunciation, Nativity, Resurrection, Ascension, Assumption)
The Five Virtues (generosity, courtesy, chastity, chivalry, piety - as in Sir Gawain)
Protection against evil and demonic forces
The Star of Bethlehem and Epiphany

architecture: Gothic cathedrals often feature pentagram window tracery
Church door carvings in France, Germany, and England
manuscripts: Medical and astronomical texts (connecting divine and natural order)

sirGawainAndTheGreenKnight.description: This anonymous Middle English poem provides the most detailed medieval explanation of the pentagram's Christian meaning. The poet describes the 'endless knot' on Gawain's shield:

poem.explanation: The five points represent: (1) Five senses kept pure, (2) Five fingers never failing, (3) Five Wounds of Christ, (4) Five Joys of Mary, (5) Five virtues of chivalry
poem.significance: Each group of five interlocks with the others, forming a complete Christian character

sirGawainAndTheGreenKnight.theologicalNote: The poem's detailed Christian explanation demonstrates how thoroughly the pentagram was integrated into medieval religious understanding.

protectiveUse.description: Medieval Christians believed the pentagram protected against evil spirits. This was not superstition but theological conviction - the wounds of Christ are the means of salvation and therefore have power over demonic forces.
protectiveUse.scriptural: This connects to passages like Revelation 12:11 ('They triumphed over him by the blood of the Lamb') and Colossians 2:15 (Christ disarming powers and authorities through the cross).

christologicalMeaning.concept: The pentagram as symbol of Christ's saving wounds focuses attention on the Passion. Each point recalls a wound; the complete figure recalls the complete sacrifice.
christologicalMeaning.meditation: Medieval devotion encouraged meditation on each wound: the pierced hands that blessed and healed, the pierced feet that walked to Calvary, the pierced side from which flowed blood and water (Church and sacraments).

mariologicalConnection.concept: The Five Joys of Mary trace salvation history from Annunciation to Assumption, with Mary as model of faithful response to God's action.
mariologicalConnection.rosary: This connects to the Joyful Mysteries of the Rosary, though the exact list varied in medieval tradition.

sacredMathematics.concept: The pentagram's embodiment of the golden ratio was seen as evidence of divine design in creation. God as the Great Mathematician ordered the universe according to beautiful proportions.
sacredMathematics.scriptural: Wisdom 11:20 ('But you have arranged all things by measure and number and weight') was cited to support the theological significance of mathematical harmony.

humanForm.vitruvianConnection: The pentagram inscribed in a circle with a human figure (later famous through Leonardo) represents the human being as microcosm of divine creation.
humanForm.imago Dei: Genesis 1:27 ('God created man in his own image') - the human form reflects divine proportions and order.

romanesque.description: Pentagrams appear in Romanesque church architecture, particularly in carved stone capitals and doorway decorations.

gothic.description: Gothic architecture extensively employed the pentagram in window tracery, rose windows, and decorative elements. The geometric precision required for Gothic construction aligned with the pentagram's sacred geometry.

renaissanceTurning.description: During the Renaissance, the pentagram began its transition from primarily Christian to occult symbol. Hermetic, alchemical, and magical texts increasingly employed it, though Christian use continued.
renaissanceTurning.agrippa: Cornelius Agrippa's 'Three Books of Occult Philosophy' (1531) systematized elemental correspondences that became standard in later occultism.

witchTrials.impact: Association with folk magic and witchcraft accusations damaged the pentagram's Christian reputation. Inquisitors sometimes identified it with suspected witches, though this was not universal.
witchTrials.irony: The symbol that had protected Christians from evil became suspected as an evil symbol - a tragic reversal of its original Christian meaning.

modernOccultism.description: Eliphas Levi (1810-1875) reinterpreted the pentagram in magical terms, popularizing the inverted pentagram as a symbol of the 'Goat of Mendes.' This occult interpretation, not the Christian one, dominates modern perception.
modernOccultism.recovery: Some contemporary Christians advocate recovering the pentagram's Christian heritage, distinguishing medieval Christian use from modern occult appropriation.

epiphany.description: The five-pointed star appears in Epiphany celebrations, representing the Star of Bethlehem that guided the Magi. Church decorations for this feast often feature stars.
epiphany.symbolism: The Magi represent the Gentiles coming to worship Christ - the star leads all nations to the Savior.

passionDevotions.description: Devotion to the Five Wounds was particularly strong in medieval piety, with special prayers, hymns, and meditations focused on each wound.
examples: The Golden Mass in honor of the Five Wounds
Stations of the Cross focusing on the wounding of Christ
Hymns like 'Salve Mundi Salutare' addressing each wound

sacredHeart.connection: Devotion to the Sacred Heart, particularly strong after St. Margaret Mary Alacoque's visions (17th century), connects to the wound in Christ's side. The pentagram's fifth point (side wound) relates to this devotion.

christianVsOccult.christianUpright: In medieval Christian use, the upright pentagram (one point up) represented spirit/Christ presiding over the four elements/material world - proper spiritual order
christianVsOccult.occultInverted: Levi's interpretation of the inverted pentagram as representing matter over spirit/the Goat of Mendes reversed the traditional meaning
christianVsOccult.significance: The same symbol can carry opposite meanings depending on orientation and interpretive framework

recoveryPossibility.argument: Just as the fish (ichthys) remained a Christian symbol despite its pre-Christian associations, and the cross was transformed from instrument of shame to glory, the pentagram could be recovered for Christian use
recoveryPossibility.caution: Given its strong modern association with Wicca and occultism, such recovery requires careful catechesis to avoid confusion

comparativeNotes.symbolicPolysemy: The pentagram demonstrates how symbols carry multiple meanings across cultures and times. The same form meant Christ's wounds to medieval Christians and elemental magic to modern occultists.

patristicAndMedievalSources.author: Hildegard of Bingen
patristicAndMedievalSources.relevance: Employs pentagrammic imagery in mystical visions of cosmic order

patristicAndMedievalSources.author: Anonymous
patristicAndMedievalSources.work: Sir Gawain and the Green Knight
patristicAndMedievalSources.relevance: Most detailed medieval Christian explanation of pentagram symbolism

patristicAndMedievalSources.author: Hugh of Saint Victor
patristicAndMedievalSources.work: On the Sacraments of the Christian Faith
patristicAndMedievalSources.relevance: Medieval theology of sacred symbols and signs

education.opportunity: Teaching about the pentagram's Christian history corrects misconceptions and demonstrates how symbols can be transformed or lost through cultural change
education.approach: Focus on the Five Wounds of Christ as the primary Christian meaning, with connection to Passion spirituality

discernment.guidance: Christians encountering pentagrams should understand context - a pentagram on a medieval church has very different meaning than one in a modern occult context
discernment.wisdom: Neither uncritical acceptance nor automatic rejection serves truth. Understanding history enables appropriate response.

freemasonry.name: Blazing Star
freemasonry.symbolism: Divine Providence, the search for light and truth, the five points of fellowship

bahai.name: Haykal (Temple)
bahai.symbolism: The human body, the temple of God, representing the head, two hands, and two feet

mormonism.usage: Appears on early Mormon temples, including the Nauvoo Temple, representing the morning star

judaism.name: Seal of Solomon (alternate form)
judaism.usage: Occasionally used alongside the hexagram in Kabbalistic contexts

ritualUsage: The pentagram is used extensively in ceremonial magic, Wiccan practice, and various esoteric traditions for: protection and banishing, invoking elemental forces, creating sacred space, meditation and visualization, consecration of tools and spaces, and as a symbol of initiation and spiritual attainment.

variations.name: Pentacle
variations.description: Pentagram enclosed in a circle, emphasizing containment and unity

variations.name: Flaming Pentagram
variations.description: Pentagram with flames at each point, representing spiritual fire

variations.name: Elemental Pentagram
variations.description: Pentagram with elemental symbols at each point

variations.name: Unicursal Hexagram
variations.description: Related six-pointed figure that can be drawn in one line, used in Thelema

variations.name: Invoking/Banishing Pentagrams
variations.description: Different starting points and directions for different magical purposes

usage: meditation, ritual magic, protection, elemental invocation, consecration, talismanic work, spiritual development

primarySources.title: Three Books of Occult Philosophy
primarySources.author: Heinrich Cornelius Agrippa
primarySources.significance: First systematic treatment of the pentagram in Western ceremonial magic

primarySources.title: Transcendental Magic: Its Doctrine and Ritual
primarySources.author: Eliphas Levi
primarySources.significance: Established modern elemental correspondences and inverted pentagram symbolism

primarySources.title: The Golden Dawn
primarySources.author: Israel Regardie
primarySources.significance: Revealed the Lesser Banishing Ritual of the Pentagram and Golden Dawn practices

primarySources.title: Liber O vel Manus et Sagittae
primarySources.author: Aleister Crowley
primarySources.significance: Thelemic pentagram rituals and elemental workings

primarySources.title: Drawing Down the Moon
primarySources.author: Margot Adler
primarySources.significance: Documents modern Wiccan and Neopagan use of the pentagram

icon:
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 64 64">
  <circle cx="32" cy="32" r="28" fill="none" stroke="#9370DB" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.6"/>
  <polygon points="32,4 41.5,24 61,24 45.5,38 52,58 32,46 12,58 18.5,38 3,24 22.5,24" fill="none" stroke="#9370DB" stroke-width="2" stroke-linejoin="round"/>
  <circle cx="32" cy="32" r="3" fill="#9370DB" opacity="0.8"/>
</svg>
origins: Ancient origins (Mesopotamia, Egypt); extensively used in Pythagorean philosophy; central to Hermetic and Western esoteric traditions
prohibitions: Inverted pentagram has different meanings - understand context
Not to be used as symbol of evil (common misconception)
Requires proper training for magical applications
Should not be worn casually without understanding
Respect varies by tradition - clarify context of use
